quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's so incredibly necessary in improving decision quality to take what's implicit and make it explicit. It's not that intuition is crap, your intuition is sometimes right. If you don't make it explicit, then you don't get to find out when it's wrong.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A practical decision-making principle: externalize intuition so you can test it, learn, and improve accuracy over time.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: People generally think the purpose of a meeting is for three things, discover, discuss, decide. The only thing that's ever supposed to happen in a meeting is the discussion part.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A contrarian meeting framework that challenges teams to separate discovery and decision-making from meetings to improve quality and efficiency.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So a pre-mortem, it's great only if you set up kill criteria. Commit to actions that you're going to take if you see those signals.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Turns pre-mortems into an actionable methodology by pairing risks with explicit triggers and pre-committed responses.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There is no such thing as a long feedback loop. And the way you choose to shorten the feedback loop is to say, what are the things that are correlated with the outcome that I eventually desire?
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A mental model for making better long-horizon decisions by identifying leading indicators correlated with the desired outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, why when you're thinking about quitting, that probably means you've already waited too long and you should have quit a while ago.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A counterintuitive decision-making heuristic: the moment you seriously consider quitting may be a lagging indicator that you should have acted earlier.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now you can assess risk, secure the trust of your customers, and automate compliance for SOC 2, ISO 27001, HIPAA and more with a single platform, Vanta.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A practical operational approach: centralize risk assessment, customer trust, and compliance automation in one system to reduce complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Get fast feedback from real people throughout the development process so that you can build the right thing the first time.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable product methodology: continuous user feedback loops reduce rework and increase the odds of building the correct solution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Companies are being asked to do more with less.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concise constraint framing that motivates prioritization and efficiency-focused decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Daniel Kahneman
quotes.text: But the thing about Danny was when you talked about it, he was the first one to tell you, "I wish priming wasn't in the book. It doesn't replicate."
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Models intellectual humility as a practical decision-making habit: openly update beliefs when evidence changes, even if it undermines your prior work.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Daniel Kahneman
quotes.text: So one of his favorite things, and he in some ways invented it, was find someone who really disagrees with you and then write a paper with them and try to figure out with them what's the study that would resolve the issue.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Introduces “adversarial collaboration” as a repeatable methodology for resolving disagreements by jointly designing decisive tests.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Daniel Kahneman
quotes.text: Kahneman and a collaborator, Angus Deaton, they published a result that got a lot of press about the relationship between money and happiness, and the idea was money doesn't buy happiness beyond $75,000.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, memorable data point/example used to illustrate how empirical claims can be tested, debated, and revisited over time.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Daniel Kahneman
quotes.text: And instead, it was Kahneman's like, "All right, let's do it together."
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Counterintuitive collaboration move: replace academic/ego combat with joint truth-seeking to resolve contested claims faster.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Daniel Kahneman
quotes.text: He was just always seeking out, it was just like everything was like, why am I wrong?
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A simple mental model for better decisions: actively search for disconfirming evidence and your own blind spots.

quotes.topic_title: Parenting advice and resilience mindset
quotes.text: But the only thing that matters really is that your kids know you love them, really know deep in their bones, know you love them.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Cuts through parenting tactics and emphasizes the single highest-leverage priority.

quotes.topic_title: Parenting advice and resilience mindset
quotes.text: Number two is at some point, you will drop your baby on its head.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A blunt normalization of inevitable mistakes that helps parents build resilience and avoid spiraling guilt.

quotes.topic_title: Parenting advice and resilience mindset
quotes.text: So I think there's just a lesson in that which is like it's a small thing, don't sweat it and don't get mad at yourself because you made a mistake.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Actionable mindset shift: treat minor parenting errors as expected and focus on learning rather than self-blame.

quotes.topic_title: Parenting advice and resilience mindset
quotes.text: Be having four, you have very little, you have no influence whatsoever basically on what your child's personality is. What you can do as a parent is make sure they say please and thank you.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A counterintuitive model of parental influence: temperament is largely fixed, so focus on teachable basics like manners.

quotes.topic_title: Parenting advice and resilience mindset
quotes.text: Nothing is as important as it seems when you're thinking about it, that's a really important one.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A decision-making heuristic for reducing overreaction and improving judgment under emotional intensity.

quotes.topic_title: Decision tools for parenting and leadership
quotes.text: Nothing is as important as it seems when you're thinking about it, that's a really important one.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A portable Kahneman heuristic to counter the focusing effect and reduce over-weighting what feels urgent in the moment.

quotes.topic_title: Decision tools for parenting and leadership
quotes.text: One of the things that I used to try to do with my kids all the time was mental time travel, which is actually a very good decision tool.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete method—projecting forward in time—to create distance from emotions and improve choices.

quotes.topic_title: Decision tools for parenting and leadership
quotes.text: A week from now when you get that test back, how do you think you're going to feel about those two choices?
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A simple prompt practitioners can use to fight present-bias by evaluating decisions from a future vantage point.

quotes.topic_title: Decision tools for parenting and leadership
quotes.text: So it's I hear you. Nevertheless, you're grounded for two weeks.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A memorable boundary-setting script that acknowledges feelings while still committing to a decision.

quotes.topic_title: Decision tools for parenting and leadership
quotes.text: But in the workplace, this is very good because employees gripe all the time at decisions that you make in leadership because they think they're right and they want their way.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that the same “heard + nevertheless” approach applies beyond parenting to leadership pushback.

quotes.topic_title: How much better can decisions get?
quotes.text: So it depends on whether you actually do the things. I mean, I think that that's what the issue is.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Highlights that decision-making improvement is less about knowing frameworks and more about consistently implementing them.

quotes.topic_title: How much better can decisions get?
quotes.text: So we can make that explicit, we can turn it into a decision rubric, we can create a structured interview process out of that.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Gives a concrete methodology: convert implicit intuition into explicit criteria and a structured process.

quotes.topic_title: How much better can decisions get?
quotes.text: And in that case, it was from about a 50% hit rate to 65. So that's pretty huge, so that's a really big difference. The problem is nobody does it.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Provides a specific performance delta from structured hiring while underscoring the real bottleneck—adoption.

quotes.topic_title: How much better can decisions get?
quotes.text: I think we think a lot more highly of our intuition than we really ought to.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Challenges the common belief that intuition is reliably accurate in complex, noisy decisions.

quotes.topic_title: How much better can decisions get?
quotes.text: So we can think there's people who don't know about it, there's people who do know about it but don't do it, and then there's people who do know about it, but do do it. And it's that last group that's so tiny.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Offers a simple adoption segmentation model that explains why tools create an outsized edge for implementers.

quotes.topic_title: Fix meetings: separate discover, discuss, decide
quotes.text: The best way to get somebody's opinion is independently of other people's opinions, independently asynchronously.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A simple, high-leverage rule for collecting input that reduces social influence and improves decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: Fix meetings: separate discover, discuss, decide
quotes.text: It's so bad for decision-making, I can't even tell you. There's cross influence, the loudest person in the room tends to then have an outsized influence on the decision, the most confident person in the room tends to have an outsized influence on the decision.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Explains the core failure mode of live “discovery” in meetings: confidence and volume distort outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Fix meetings: separate discover, discuss, decide
quotes.text: Here's the thing that I think is the easiest to change, is to realize the only thing that's ever supposed to happen in a meeting is the discussion part.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A clear framework shift: separate discover/discuss/decide and reserve meetings for discussion only.

quotes.topic_title: Fix meetings: separate discover, discuss, decide
quotes.text: And there's a word for that, which is nominal group. So it's a group that at that moment is working independently and asynchronously of each other.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Names the methodology for structured async input collection, making it easier to adopt and teach.

quotes.topic_title: Fix meetings: separate discover, discuss, decide
quotes.text: So the decision should not be made in a room, it's made either.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A counterintuitive process rule that reduces hierarchy and conformity effects during decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Census had a 10X increase in pipeline with the LinkedIn startup team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete performance example showing potential pipeline impact from LinkedIn Ads for a B2B startup.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: For Webflow, after ramping up on LinkedIn in Q4, they had the highest marketing source revenue quarter to date.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific case study tying increased LinkedIn investment to record marketing-sourced revenue.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With LinkedIn Ads, you'll have direct access to and can build relationships with decision-makers, including 950 million members, 180 million senior execs and over 10 million C-level executives.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Memorable scale and audience composition data point for reaching senior B2B buyers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In tech, LinkedIn generated two to five X higher return on ad spend than any other social media platforms.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Comparative ROAS claim that can inform channel selection and budget allocation decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Audiences on LinkedIn have two times the buying power of the average web audience, and you'll work with a partner who respects the B2B world you operate in.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Positioning statement combining a buyer-quality metric with a B2B-specific brand promise.

quotes.topic_title: DRI concerns: making people feel heard
quotes.text: So here's the really wonderful thing about moving from a coercive model to really, I guess you could say a model of curiosity, right? You want to be curious, not coercive, which means that the way that people in the meeting are talking about what their opinions are is in the mode of conveying information, not trying to convince anybody.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A clear, memorable reframing of meeting dynamics from persuasion to information-sharing that reduces defensiveness and improves decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: DRI concerns: making people feel heard
quotes.text: But as soon as you say, "Are we all in agreement? Are we all in alignment?" And as soon as you're allowing people, and I'm sure you've been in these meetings, right? If you allow people to interrupt, if you allow people to say this, "I think you're wrong", "I disagree", "Here's why", those are all very coercive things to have happen.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Identifies common “alignment” behaviors that unintentionally create coercion and shut down real participation.

quotes.topic_title: DRI concerns: making people feel heard
quotes.text: Now, everybody independently now gives their forecast with a rationale for why they believe that. And then you come into the room and you run a discussion where everybody's getting to say what their estimate was and why they believe that, and people are getting to ask questions. "I have a question" always is a clarification, it's just I don't understand.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A practical meeting method (independent inputs + rationale + clarification-only questions) that surfaces information without turning into debate.

quotes.topic_title: DRI concerns: making people feel heard
quotes.text: So I say, "So what I heard you say is that not all functions are created equal in terms of how well they work remotely or how well they work in person or what the flexibility might be. So what you're saying is there're functions that have to be in person. Period. And then other functions where that collaborative element being in the same office would be more important versus some functions where being remote is totally fine. Is that what you meant?"
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A concrete facilitator script for reflecting back someone’s view so they feel accurately understood before any decision is made.

quotes.topic_title: DRI concerns: making people feel heard
quotes.text: So for example, particularly if you're senior, if you say, "I think this is going to take three months to launch" and I was thinking four weeks, you're never going to hear four weeks from me, ever. But if we get those opinions independently, you will actually hear that I think it's going to take four weeks.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation about hierarchy-driven conformity—and why independent estimates are necessary to reveal true disagreement.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing independent input and private voting
quotes.text: I mean, I just think it's really important that once you get above an end of one, you shouldn't necessarily expect the people to agree, which I think is just really important.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Reframes disagreement as normal and expected in group decisions, reducing pressure for consensus and enabling better aggregation of independent views.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing independent input and private voting
quotes.text: They go to a forum. So I don't know what your vote is.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A concrete mechanism for private voting that preserves independence and prevents social influence from contaminating judgments.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing independent input and private voting
quotes.text: The other thing that I'll just add to what you said is that you can actually be in the same room together and still discover information independently.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Introduces an on-the-fly method to capture independent input even during live meetings, not just in pre-work.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing independent input and private voting
quotes.text: Something comes up, like someone suggests some new feature or something like that, and then people start saying, "Yeah, but that's going to take..." And you go, "Stop. Okay, everybody take out a piece of paper."
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A memorable facilitation script practitioners can use to pause groupthink and quickly elicit independent estimates in real time.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing independent input and private voting
quotes.text: And this is good for more than just brainstorming. It's for forecasting, any kind of project planning, budgeting.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Generalizes the independent-input workflow beyond ideation to core operational processes where biased group discussion often derails accuracy.

quotes.topic_title: First Round context and long-term decision quality
quotes.text: The first one was, well, the kind of decision-making you're talking about we don't need to do because we just know a good founder when we see one.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Highlights a common but risky reliance on intuition over explicit decision processes in venture and business decisions.

quotes.topic_title: First Round context and long-term decision quality
quotes.text: And as I just said to you, okay, I have no doubt, but don't you want [inaudible 00:46:52] make that explicit?
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Pushes practitioners to convert tacit judgment into explicit criteria to improve decisions and learning.

quotes.topic_title: First Round context and long-term decision quality
quotes.text: There's all sorts of great things that come from making it explicit, not just in terms of the increase in decision quality in the moment, but it actually allows you to close feedback loops much better.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Offers a practical methodology: explicit decision-making improves both immediate quality and long-term feedback/learning.

quotes.topic_title: First Round context and long-term decision quality
quotes.text: But the one that I really found very interesting was being told, "Well, what you're talking about doesn't apply because our feedback loops are a decade."
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Challenges the conventional excuse that long feedback cycles make decision-quality frameworks irrelevant.

quotes.topic_title: First Round context and long-term decision quality
quotes.text: The first thing that I would say is, oh, poker is much noisier than you think because when I win a hand, I have no idea why.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Reframes “fast feedback” as often illusory, underscoring the need to separate outcomes from decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: No long feedback loops: create proxy signals
quotes.text: But separately from that, the main thing that I said was, how could you possibly think that the feedback loop is 10 years?
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Challenges the default assumption that outcomes like exits define the only feedback loop, prompting practitioners to look for nearer-term signals.

quotes.topic_title: No long feedback loops: create proxy signals
quotes.text: And I said, "Oh, I'm sorry, do you invest? And then you go to sleep like Rip Van Winkle? And then you wake up 10 years later and you go, 'Hey, how'd that go?' Or are there all sorts of things that happen in between?"
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A vivid metaphor that reframes long-horizon decisions as having many intermediate checkpoints you can learn from.

quotes.topic_title: No long feedback loops: create proxy signals
quotes.text: Well, I know that", but have you ever had a company that exited for more than a billion dollars that did not fund at Series A? And the answer is no. And I'm like, okay. So it sounds like that's necessary. Might not be sufficient, but it's necessary.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Introduces the “necessary but not sufficient” milestone test as a practical way to create proxy signals for eventual success.

quotes.topic_title: No long feedback loops: create proxy signals
quotes.text: There is no such thing as a long feedback loop. You can make a decision about how long the feedback loop is. That is your choice to live in a long feedback loop, and you can choose to shorten the feedback loop.
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: A memorable principle that puts feedback-loop length under the practitioner’s control via measurement choices.

quotes.topic_title: No long feedback loops: create proxy signals
quotes.text: And the way you choose to shorten the feedback loop is to say, what are the things that are necessary but not sufficient?
quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.context: Actionable method: define leading indicators that must occur en route to the desired outcome to accelerate learning cycles.
